posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14376255
The literal definition of atheism:
>"a-" = without
>"-theism" = the belief in a god or gods
>atheism = without the belief in a god or gods; more succintly, "without the belief in a god or gods"
Strictly speaking, an atheist is, or rather ought, to be someone who simply lacks the belief in any sort of divine power.
However, that literal definition is rarely adhered to in the real world.
Most people who call themselves "atheists" or subscribe to "atheism" are not merely "without" belief, in fact quite the opposite, they BELIEVE, wholeheartedly, and with the knowledge certitude of faith, that there is no god or gods. These "atheists" are in fact "anti-theists" - people who are against theism altogether, instead of merely lacking theism. These are the people who are often described as "militant" atheists, and tend to be reviled everywhere and by everybody, including real, genuine atheists, who typically mask their atheism with the word "agnostic", in order to avoid being associated with people who have made a religion out of being against religion.
"Gnosis" is the Greek word for "knowledge" so an agnostic is a person "without knowledge", i.e. has not been convinced of any evidence in point of favor for theism or against it, and thus takes the actual atheistical view in its literal definition, that to have no knowledge is to have no belief.

posts.com:
English will be the main (ie, most widely spoken) language for a very long time. Secularism is central to Irish Republicanism and always has been, and it's highly unlikely that it would ever go away.
>but why can't they just relearn Irish?
The status of the Irish language in Ireland is thus:
>Republic of Ireland
Everyone learns it in school, a bit. It's treated generally as an afterthought; the vast majority of people know a handful of words, many know a few phrases, some can hold a semi-coherent conversation. A lot are in that stage of learning a language where they recognise/can understand things, but can't really speak it themselves. There exists many gaeltachts where everyone is fluent, but they remain firmly a small minority.
>Northern Ireland
Ulster Unionists get scared by it so it's still widely suppressed. Where it is spoken (Derry, Belfast, etc) it's spoken well and widely.

It's highly likely that Irish will remain the "first" language and the "official" language. We are seeing a new age of revival kickstarting (Irish language speakers in the north are the instigators of it) which is snowballing quite quickly; countless resources are being secured and used to develop grassroots Irish language courses. Don't get too excited-we're decades away from noticeable change.

All this aside, the notion that partition can continue mostly relies on Ulster Unionism keeping hold of a majority in the north-they no longer have that. In fact, Sinn Féin are now the largest party. Unionism bleeds votes to the "centre" which bleeds votes to Nationalism. Ireland will be united but it won't be the happening everyone hopes for-that'll come after unification happens.

>>14374484
No, for many reasons like >>14374542 said, but I'll also mention that Homo erectus and Homo habilis were long extinct by 124,000 years ago (the oldest known admixture event between Homo sapiens and this unknown species), and that Eastern, Southern, and Central African hunter-gatherers have two unknown species of human in them, yet they don't appear to get the same racism against them as West Africans do. Finally, we can assume it wouldn't be Homo erectus due to the assumed genetic divergence between this species and ourselves: 360,000-1,020,000 years ago, with a general mean estimate of around 620,000 years. This means that whatever this species was, it too was descended from Homo erectus like our LCA with Denisovans and Homo erectus, and was probably similar in some way. Turns out there's an African and Southern European species that fits this mold: Homo bodoensis.

There's also the DNA itself, ranging from as low as 2% and up to 19%, but Robert "Atlantis is real" Sepehr didn't bring up the mean estimate of 6.6-7% on purpose, because while it is higher on average, it's not high enough for his agenda. The two hominins on the left and center are Homo bodoensis, the one on the right is Homo sapiens idaltu.

>>14377404
The oldest elements that can be dated in the mythos(including the Scandinavian texts) are those referring to Ermanric(a real Gothic chieftain living in Black Sea region somewhere in 4th century).

The whole mythos is a mashup of a numerous different narratives(most likely songs/poems) about different historical figures, coupled with cryptic allusions to mythology.
We know, from the older English poetry that originally it was Sigmund who killed the dragon, not his son Siegfried, so that's the first merge in it. Then there's also the arc Siegfried goes through himself which is reminiscent of real events involving some Merovingian princes struggling for power. Gunther going to feast with Attila is an allusion to yet another historical event - the destruction of Burgundian aristocracy north-west of Rhein in 5th century(a plot by Aetius) that played out basically the same, whether Hagen was part of that narrative from the get go or whether he taken from even other lost source is anyone's guess. If you read the version in Thidreksaga, there are some elements of Saga of Heidrek the Wise in the Ermanric-related parts. Hildebrand is probably some Longobard hero, Dietrich is Theodoric the Great mythologized and so on and so on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14377188
It's the most common way people on the Internet try to sound smart without actually knowing anything about philosophy. People who know what they're talking about typically don't waste time name-dropping fallacies; they point what's wrong with an argument and move on. Anyway, debate nerds tend to obsess way too much over informal fallacies. With formal fallacies, there's a very clear argument form that you can identify and express in logical notation and prove is invalid. With informal fallacies there are no such criteria, and generally, it's trivial to make such arguments non-fallacious by just adding an extra premise. For example, you can easily do this with arguments that appeal to authority. People call these fallacious, but generally they involve the implicit premise that some authority should be trusted. In such cases, it would be much charitable to just bring to light the implicit premise instead of just crying about fallacies.

Judaism, as an ethno-religious identity, pretty much started in Babylon.
Basically, the story is, Judah was an iron age kingdom is the south Levant. it was a tributary of the Babylonian Empire. One fine day, Judah rebels against Babylon, and the Babylonians march on their capital at Jerusalem, conquer it, and dissolve the kingdom. They round up the ruling class of Jerusalem and force them to live in Babylon and install Babylonian governors. Judah is no more.

Now, obviously, that isn't the end of the story. An odd 70 years after the destruction of Judah, Babylon itself gets conquered by Persia. The Persians followed the religion of Zoroastrianism, which was persecuted by the Babylonians, so part of the Persians goal was to reverse all the religious discrimination committed by the Babylonians and rebuild the temples that were destroyed as well as restore religious rule in those regions.

The descendants of the rulers of Jerusalem who were living in Babylon at the time went before the King of Persia and argued that they were united under a religion called "Judaism" and that they deserved to be restored to their rule over the southern Levant. So the concept of Judaism as a religion was born.

Things like the Kingdom of Judah, and the experience of the rulers living in Babylon (known as the Babylonian Exile) have been very "spiritualized" in the Abrahamic scope. For all of Jewish and subsequent Christian history, they understood the spiritual conflict between the faith (Judah, Israel) and the outside world (Babylon). And use of these terms goes back to a spiritual understanding of the Exile.

In the Revelation to John, John describes the "Bride of Christ" and the "Whore of Babylon". And its this same poetic reference to the Church and greater society respectively.

>>14373785
A vassal is made by a formal agreement with a superior state for protection, usually with tribute payed for this protection. It's a more antiquated term and rarely ever seen in our modern geopolitical context, and has been replaced by puppet state, protectorate, client state, associated state, or satelite state, each of which has context associated with it. Usually vassals, and the other terms listed have little control over their foreign affairs, and their domestic affairs are often vetted by their superior.
What NATO could be characterised as in reference to the United States, is something more-like informal empire, something Britain practiced in areas such as Latin America, whereas in India, a number of princely states were actual vassals, and then in adjacent areas such as Afghanistan, Nepal, and Bhutan, were protectorates with greater autonomy in domestic affairs but none in foreign affairs. With informal empire, certain facets of subordinate nations are geared towards the benefit of the superior nation, and to which changing these is repugnant to the superior nation. There were no formal agreements between the US and many of these states in reference to foreign or domestic policy, but informal expectations of certain policies to remain.

Another more subtle example is the CIA's role in the Dismissal of Australian PM Gough Whitlam, who intended to close Pine Gap, a massive surveillance base in the centre of Australia, used to this day, and at the time, used by the US aid in global surveillance and military uses during the Second Indochina War.
Britain you could argue is more of an ally but one increasingly dependent on the US, often acting in support of US policy, especially since one of its last independent foreign adventures ended in massive embarassment and greater reliance on the US for trade, the Suez Crisis. France on the otherhand, is most definiately an ally, who's goals often overlap with American ones, but since their economy is not entirely dependent on the US, are free to pursue their own foreign policy, as seen in Francafrique, with the US leaving almost entirely to France.
The Warsaw Pact and Communist Mongolia were far more akin to vassalage, and would be aptly characterised as satelite states of the USSR due to the overt influence Moscow exercised over local communist parties and security services of these nations. Whereas in the modern-day, CIS is more of an informal empire.

>>14375063

It was a labor problem. When it was just the British areas, it was essentially unlimited land but a very limited labor force. Europe had the opposite problem, but not only were the English not going to import Catholics from Spain or Italy or Poland, but they didn't really want Germans or the Dutch or anyone else because A) they weren't English, B) their own kings and princes might not let them emigrate in the first place and C) they wouldn't be politically reliable, meaning if enough of say the Dutch ones were in the Carolinas they might decide to make it a Dutch colony.

As far as having to establish housing and whatnot, it cost more money to house and clothe slaves, but they were legally property and couldn't just up and leave. With tenement farmers, they might get money in rent and crops, but the farmers could also just up and leave at will leaving the land owner with negative cash flow if the land was unproductive because no one was working it or if they left a harvest ungathered or something.

Not to mention the strict social structure in the southern colonies and states meant that the slaves were the bottom rung giving even the poorest of whites someone to look down on which was kind of a release to social pressures and a common rallying point.
